sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a neutralization reaction
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide at 25℃? The reaction equation is HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O (l).
message_2:
The standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) at 25℃ can be found using the heat of formation values for the reactants and products.

ΔH° = Σ ΔH°f (products) - Σ ΔH°f (reactants)

For the given reaction:
HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O (l)

The standard enthalpy of formation (ΔH°f) values at 25℃ are as follows:
HCl (aq): -167.2 kJ/mol
NaOH (aq): -469.15 kJ/mol
NaCl (aq): -407.27 kJ/mol
H2O (l): -285.83 kJ/mol

Now, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction:

ΔH° = [(-407.27 kJ/mol) + (-285.83 kJ/mol)] - [(-167.2 kJ/mol) + (-469.15 kJ/mol)]
ΔH° = (-693.1 kJ/mol) - (-636.35 kJ/mol)
ΔH° = -56.75 kJ/mol

Therefore, the standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide at 25℃ is -56.75 kJ/mol.
